qas.question: What is one of the historical certain facts about Jesus?
Do non-Christians agree that the Crucifixion happened?

answers.text: the crucifixion of Jesus is as certain as any historical fact can be

qas.question: Is the exact reason known that Jesus got Crucified for?

answers.text: the exact reasons for the death of Jesus are hard to determine

qas.question: Who said the Crucifixion of Jesus is firmly established.
Who said the Baptism of Jesus was Univeral Assent?
What kind of confirmation is there about the life of Pontius Pilate?
What do Eddy and Boyd believe about Pilate and and how he shaped the life of the Jewish people?
How many trials had Pilate presided over before Jesus?
What does the crucifixion of Jesus mean for understanding the life of Pilate?
Why did Pilate decide to turn Jesus over to the Jews?

context: The <a0_0>baptism of Jesus<a0_0/> and his crucifixion are considered to be two historically certain facts about Jesus. <a4_0>James Dunn<a4_0/> states that these "two facts in the life of Jesus command almost universal assent" and "rank so high on the 'almost impossible to doubt or deny' scale of historical facts" that they are <b8_0>often the starting points<b8_0/> for the study of the historical Jesus. Bart Ehrman states that the crucifixion of Jesus on the orders of Pontius Pilate is the most certain element about him. John Dominic Crossan states that <a1_0>the crucifixion of Jesus is as certain as any historical fact can be<a1_0/>. <a3_0>Eddy<a3_0/> and Boyd state that it is now "firmly established" that there is <b5_0>non-Christian<b5_0/> confirmation of the crucifixion of Jesus. Craig Blomberg states that most scholars in the third quest for the historical Jesus consider the crucifixion <b6_0>indisputable<b6_0/>. Christopher M. Tuckett states that, although <a2_0>the exact reasons for the death of Jesus are <b9_0>hard to determine<b9_0/><a2_0/>, <b7_0>one<b7_0/> of the indisputable facts about him is that he was crucified.
